content.html:
To be pedantic, we should expect that the message has all of these fields before accessing them.

EXPECT_TRUE(msg.has_xyz());
EXPECT_EQ(msgs::Convert(msg.xyz()), math::Vector3(0, 0, 1));

content.raw:
ya good idea, added `JointFromSDF` and `AxisFromSDF` functions to `msgs.cc` and added unit tests. `JointMaker` now uses the `JointFromSDF` fucntion

753402d
content.html:
ya good idea, added JointFromSDF and AxisFromSDF functions to msgs.cc and added unit tests. JointMaker now uses the JointFromSDF fucntion

753402d

update.description:

fixes issue #1508, #1484, 

and part of #1483 (updated joint visual to be thinner and more transparent)
update.title: Update JointInspector to use ConfigWidget

content.raw:
There is a `JointToSDF` function, and there are some other `FromSDF` functions (ie. [GeometryFromSDF](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/92a5ef6ae5194b42b24a8758421048acbf4c7997/gazebo/msgs/msgs.cc#cl-691)), but not yet `JointFromSDF`.

I support this idea. If we write the code anywhere, it may as well be in msgs.cc, so it could be re-used and tested in `UNIT_msgs_TEST`.
content.html:
There is a JointToSDF function, and there are some other FromSDF functions (ie. GeometryFromSDF), but not yet JointFromSDF.

I support this idea. If we write the code anywhere, it may as well be in msgs.cc, so it could be re-used and tested in UNIT_msgs_TEST.

content.raw:
You can create an empty `joint` element with:
~~~
sdf::ElementPtr jointElem = msgs::JointToSDF(msgs::Joint());
~~~
Then just call `Get` on all the fields from which you want default values.
content.html:
You can create an empty joint element with:

sdf::ElementPtr jointElem = msgs::JointToSDF(msgs::Joint());

Then just call Get on all the fields from which you want default values.

content.raw: Going to need a `QScrollArea` somewhere, the inspector's height doesn't fit my screen for joints with 2 axes.
content.html: Going to need a QScrollArea somewhere, the inspector's height doesn't fit my screen for joints with 2 axes.
